description: From Middle English hummen (“to hum, buzz, drone, make a murmuring sound to cover embarrassment”); akin to Dutch hommelen (“to bumble, buzz”), dialectal Dutch hommen (“to buzz, hum”), Middle High German hummen (“to hum”), probably ultimately of imitative origin.

entries.meaning: A hummed tune, i.e. created orally with lips closed.
An often indistinct sound resembling human humming.
examples: They could hear a hum coming from the kitchen, and found the dishwasher on.

entries.meaning: Busy activity, like the buzz of a beehive.
(with article) A phenomenon, or collection of phenomena, involving widespread reports of a persistent and invasive low-frequency humming, rumbling, or droning noise not audible to all people.

verbs.description: hum (third-person singular simple present hums, present participle humming, simple past and past participle hummed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a sound from the vocal chords without pronouncing any real words, with one's lips closed.
examples: We are humming happily along with the music.
The team ominously hummed “We shall overcome” as they came back onto the field after the break.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To drone like certain insects naturally do in motion, or sounding similarly
(intransitive) To buzz, be busily active like a beehive
examples: The streets were humming with activity.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To produce low sounds which blend continuously

examples: This room really hums — have you ever tried spring cleaning, mate?

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK, dated, slang) To flatter by approving; to cajole; to deceive or impose upon; to humbug.
